explanation:
For determining whether any operations in OS_FileOpen_Impl are dead (i.e. executed but removable without changing behavior) the following symbols are needed:

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: macro/function used to obtain 'impl'; must know whether it has side-effects and how it maps token->record (removing the call could change behaviour).  
- OS_impl_filehandle_table: the table argument to the above macro; required to understand lookup semantics and side-effects.  
- OS_impl_file_internal_record_t: type of 'impl' so we can determine whether assignments impl->fd and impl->selectable have observable effects elsewhere (if fields are unused, the writes might be dead).  
- OS_object_token_t: type and dereference semantics for '*token' used with the table-get; needed to know if evaluating '*token' has side-effects.  
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: appears in the static call graph and may be what the table macro invokes; its behaviour and side-effects must be known.  
- OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE, OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE: input flag bits used in branching and to form os_perm; need their definitions to know which branches are possible at runtime.  
- OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS: added unconditionally to os_perm; may contain bits (e.g. O_NONBLOCK) that affect later code (impl->selectable) so its value is required to see if that assignment is meaningful.  
- OS_WRITE_ONLY, OS_READ_ONLY, OS_READ_WRITE: symbolic access_mode values used in switch. Need their definitions and whether any values are impossible (which could render cases dead).  
- O_WRONLY, O_RDONLY, O_RDWR, O_CREAT, O_TRUNC, O_NONBLOCK: platform open/flag constants combined into os_perm; required to reason whether bits like O_CREAT/O_TRUNC/O_NONBLOCK can be set and whether open() semantics make some code (e.g. mode usage, selectable assignment) redundant.  
- S_IRUSR, S_IWUSR, S_IRGRP, S_IWGRP, S_IROTH, S_IWOTH: file mode bits passed to open when creating files; required to determine if the os_mode computation has any observable effect (mode is only used if O_CREAT present).  
- open: the POSIX/system call; its semantics and side-effects (file creation/truncation, return value, errno behavior) are necessary to know whether the open invocation and its error handling are essential.  
- errno, strerror: used in the error path OS_DEBUG("open(...): %s", strerror(errno)); need to know whether strerror(errno) or reading errno has side-effects (normally none) and whether the debug output has observable effect.  
- OS_DEBUG: macro/function used for logging on error. If OS_DEBUG is a no-op in builds, the call may be dead; its definition/side-effects must be known.  
- OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR: return codes used by the function; required to determine whether returning those values has observable effects and to reason about whether code paths that only change the return value are meaningful.

Knowing the above symbols lets an analyst determine which assignments, flag manipulations, and calls have externally observable effects (file-system side-effects, table state changes, logging) and therefore whether any executed operations in OS_FileOpen_Impl could be removed without changing program behaviour (i.e. are dead code).
